poem:
Title: "Stateside"

In Mar-a-Lago's palm-stroked glow,
Cameron whispers, soft yet bold,
Ideas of lands afar, stories told.
Oh, the divisive Tory show,
Though cracks appear, they seldom fold.

Eyes cast eastward, intent, behold,
This foreign heart in stateside mold;
For Gaza weeps and Israel holds,
A passive player in Charm's cold goal,
In this ballet of power, bought and sold.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "There are Tory splits over Gaza, but the party is only really going in one direction – towards Israel | Katy Balls When David Cameron touched down in Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida for a meeting with the former president this week, his mind was on one thing: Ukraine. The foreign secretary has made no secret of the fact that he wants to use his stateside charm offensive to build support among divided Republicans". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: There are Tory splits over Gaza, but the party is only really going in one direction – towards Israel | Katy Balls When David Cameron touched down in Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida for a meeting with the former president this week, his mind was on one thing: Ukraine. The foreign secretary has made no secret of the fact that he wants to use his stateside charm offensive to build support among divided Republicans
